 Seattle District 2 Council race: Eddie Lin runs on housing affordability  
  Oct. 18, 2025 at 6:00 am  
 
 
 
    
 
  
 
  
 
 
 By  
 Alexandra Yoon-Hendricks  
Seattle Times staff reporter   
 
When Eddie Lin first moved to Seattle more than 20 years ago, he and his then-girlfriend scraped by with low-paying jobs while earning college degrees. It wasn’t easy, he said, but it was doable. 
But the reality of an affordable city with opportunity for all seems to be slipping away. 
Lin and his now-wife have raised their two children in the Beacon Hill neighborhood, “but I don’t know how they’re going to afford to live here,” he said. His mother, now 86, recently retired and is planning to move to the city. On a fixed income with limited savings, the rental market is looking tough, he said. 
“We see our city transforming, and not in a good direction on affordability,” said Lin, 48, on a recent morning at The Station coffee shop on Beacon Hill. “It’s not easy to change trajectories, but we do have things that we can do.”
Lin, an assistant attorney at the Seattle city attorney’s office currently on sabbatical, is running for the City Council District 2 seat left open after Tammy Morales stepped down in January, triggering a special election. His challenger is Adonis Ducksworth, communications and policy adviser at the Seattle Department of Transportation. 
District 2 encompasses Beacon Hill, Chinatown International District, Columbia City, Rainier Beach and Seward Park. It is the city’s most racially diverse district and among its most economically mixed.

Tackling housing affordability, and the issues surrounding it like homelessness and public safety, are central to Lin’s campaign. To promote a flourishing community, Seattle and Washington state must increase taxes on big businesses and wealthy residents, he said, while reducing the financial burden on working families and low-income households. 
Most of his work at the Seattle city attorney’s office has been with the city’s Office of Housing, where he implemented policies related to affordable housing, new development and anti-displacement. 
He helped negotiate the transfer of surplus property from Sound Transit and the University of Washington to the city for affordable housing construction in South Seattle, and shepherded the Four Amigos affordable housing project in Columbia City.  
“I bring that skill set of understanding housing finance, understanding our regulations,” Lin said.  
His experience and priorities appear to have resonated — in the Aug. 5 primary, Lin received about 47% of the vote, while his challenger Ducksworth received about 29%. But Lin, whose public service work remains relatively unknown to many, continues to hit the pavement and meet voters.
Moving to Seattle 
Lin grew up in North Carolina and Massachusetts, before moving to Minnesota to attend Macalester College where he met his wife. 
 
Advertising 
 
   
She graduated, but Lin had yet to finish school, having struggled with some mental health challenges. Ready to leave the Midwest, they road tripped across the West Coast before settling in Seattle in the late 1990s.
His wife taught reading at Dunlap Elementary as an AmeriCorps tutor, and Lin picked up odd jobs. Renting an apartment in Interbay, Lin completed his credits and graduated, while his wife earned a master’s degree at the University of Washington in 2001.
The couple moved to Oakland, Calif., where Lin got a job as a receptionist at a law firm and his wife became a teacher and active member of her union. Lin later joined a San Francisco firm that represented labor groups and championed progressive causes around living wages and voting rights, inspiring him to go to law school.   

“It was just very exciting for me to see attorneys doing this very impactful work,” Lin said. 
They returned to Seattle, and Lin went on to work as an attorney at Perkins Coie. But in the back of his mind, Lin said, he wanted to do something more community service oriented, a feeling that grew stronger when President Donald Trump was elected in 2016. 
Housing affordability
Long term, the city needs more dense, walkable neighborhoods with good public transit, Lin said. 
 
Advertising 
 


   
“That’s how we’re going to address this multitude of issues around affordability, around climate change, around resilience, around public safety,” Lin said.
The city needs to make it easier and cheaper to build all housing types, he said. Seattle’s growth plan should have included more neighborhood centers, he said, and eliminated parking minimums.
Lin said he supports broader renter protections, such as the recently passed statewide cap on annual rent increases. He also wants to increase city dollars to help keep affordable housing developers and nonprofit groups up and running.

Stephanie Velasco, a city planning educator who’s worked with Lin, said he is adept at navigating complicated issues. She pointed to his work in implementing the city’s “community preference” housing policy, which encourages city-funded housing projects to consider neighborhood ties when selecting occupants.
“As the lawyer in the room … he could’ve really easily said, ‘No, there’s too much risk,’ ” Velasco said.
Instead, Lin helped ensure the policy was shielded from the lawsuits other cities saw over similar efforts, but remained an effective tool to promote racial equity, Velasco said.

Homelessness
For too long, District 2 has been the primary victim of Seattle’s failure to address homelessness, said Sharon Maeda, a longtime activist in South Seattle and former journalist, referencing Little Saigon and ongoing public safety issues there.  
Maeda said she’s been disappointed before by candidates, but Lin impressed her with his understanding of what’s working — and what’s not. 
“You can’t do it overnight, and what I appreciate about Eddie the most is he really is a thoughtful thinker, and he knows how to pull pieces together,” she said. 

Lin does not support the mayor’s effort to increase encampment removals, saying it’s a costly policy that traumatizes and pushes people around while failing to address root causes of homelessness. 
The city needs to increase its behavioral health services and drug treatment capacity, build more low-barrier shelters and fund more supportive housing, Lin said. 
Public safety
On a recent weekend of doorknocking, Lin came across Ronald Cabang at his childhood home, helping his parents fry lumpia in the garage. When Lin asked Cabang what city officials should prioritize, the answer was quick. 
 
Advertising 
 
   
Just last week, Cabang said, someone snatched his mother’s necklace right off her neck as she was gardening. She didn’t report the incident to police.
“Her English isn’t really good, so they don’t really communicate with police officers,” Cabang said. “They feel like they just have to deal with things but at the same time I can’t do anything either.”
Stories like that are part of why Lin supports hiring more police officers, he said, with a focus on hiring diverse officers who speak different languages. He also wants to beef up youth programs to reduce gun violence and delinquency. 
Lin said the city should invest more in its CARE department, the nonemergency police alternative. The Seattle Police Department overall, he said, is in need of greater accountability and civilian oversight. 
Progressive revenue 
Lin is a staunch critic of the state’s regressive tax code, which forces the city’s poorest residents to contribute a greater share of their income toward taxes than wealthier neighbors. As a council member, Lin said he would work with state lawmakers to advocate for a state income tax. 
He would like to see a local capital gains tax or a higher rate for the city’s existing JumpStart tax initiative, a payroll tax on large businesses with high-earning employees intended to fund affordable housing. 
“We’re never going to be able to meet the needs of our community without fixing our upside down tax code,” Lin said. 
 
 
 Alexandra Yoon-Hendricks: 206-464-2246 or ayoonhendricks@seattletimes.com. Alexandra Yoon-Hendricks is a race and equity reporter at The Seattle Times whose work focuses on the region’s diverse communities and the political, economic and social challenges they face.        View Comments
